overview: Information on protecting country landscapes and the funding available for farmers and rural landowners
title: Protecting rural landscapes and features

table.body:
You have certain legal obligations to manage and maintain land with:

* [trees and woodland](/protecting-rural-landscapes-and-features/trees-and-woodland "trees and woodland")
* [hedgerows or watercourses](/protecting-rural-landscapes-and-features/hedgerows-and-watercourses "hedgerows or watercourses")
* [dry stone walls](/protecting-rural-landscapes-and-features/dry-stone-walls "dry stone walls") 

You also have certain obligations if you own or occupy a [scheduled monument](/protecting-rural-landscapes-and-features/scheduled-monuments "scheduled monuments"). 

Rural landscapes and features are protected in various different ways, for example:

* by planning policies and laws
* through [the Rural Development Programme for England](http://www.defra.gov.uk/rural/rdpe/what-is-rdpe/ "Rural Development Programme for England"){:rel="external"}
* through ['cross compliance'](http://www.defra.gov.uk/farming-advice/cross-compliance/ "cross compliance"){:rel="external"} - this is the requirement for farmers to meet certain standards in farming practices and land management

There are various [funding schemes](/protecting-rural-landscapes-and-features/funding-and-cross-compliance "funding schemes") which support farmers and people who own land in rural areas.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
The following schemes provide funding to help protect rural landscapes and features:

* [The Single Payment Scheme](http://www.defra.gov.uk/food-farm/farm-manage/single-pay/ "Single Payment Scheme"){:rel="external"} is the main 
agricultural subsidy scheme in the EU and supports environmentally friendly farming practices
 
* [The English Woodland Grant Scheme](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/ewgs "English Woodland Grant Scheme"){:rel="external"} supports existing woodlands and encourages the creation of new ones

* [Environmental Stewardship](http://www.defra.gov.uk/food-farm/land-manage/stewardship/ "Environmental Stewardship"){:rel="external"} offers financial rewards for good land management which improves the quality of the environment.

$D[Download 'Look after your land with Environmental Stewardship' (PDF, 2.5MB)](http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/file/110014 "'Download ‘Look after your land with Environmental Stewardship' (PDF, 1.35 MB)"){:rel="external"}$D

##Cross compliance

['Cross compliance'](http://www.defra.gov.uk/farming-advice/cross-compliance/ "cross compliance"){:rel="external"} is the requirement for farming practices to meet certain standards so that farmers can get funding from the EU and UK rural development schemes.

To qualify for funding, farmers must meet:

* [Statutory Management Requirements](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/bdotg/action/layer?r.l1=1081597476&r.l2=1082184851&r.l3=1083731980&r.l4=1083830171&topicId=1083561575 "Statutory Management Requirements"){:rel="external"}
* standards of [Good Agricultural and Environmental Condition (GAEC)](http://www.businesslink.gov.uk/bdotg/action/detail?itemId=1083571670&r.l1=1081597476&r.l2=1082184851&r.l3=1083731939&r.l4=1083571262&r.s=m&type=RESOURCES "GAEC"){:rel="external"}

The Department for Environment Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) produces detailed information on what you need to do to [meet cross compliance requirements.](http://rpa.defra.gov.uk/rpa/index.nsf/UIMenu/6EB355EA8482EA61802573B1003D2469?Opendocument "Defra information on cross compliance" ){:rel="external"}


$C
**Defra cross compliance helpline**  
0845 345 1302
$C


*[EU]: European Union
*[Defra]: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs
*[GAEC]: Good Agricultural and Environmental Condition
table.title: Funding and cross compliance

table.body:
Hedgerows and watercourses (streams or rivers) are important habitats for many wildlife species and play an important role in farming. 

If you own land with hedgerows or watercourses, you must do everything you reasonably can to keep green cover (natural vegetation) on land:

* within 2 metres of the centre of a hedgerow, watercourse or field ditch
* within 1 metre of the top of the bank of a watercourse or field ditch

^It's against the law to remove or destroy certain hedgerows without permission from your local planning authority.^

You must also make sure you don’t:

* cultivate or apply fertilisers or pesticides on these strips of green cover
* remove hedgerows without written consent from your local authority
* cut or trim hedgerows between 1 March and 31 July

$D[Download 'GAEC 14 - Rules on protection of hedgerows and watercourses' (PDF, 1.08MB)](http://rpa.defra.gov.uk/rpa/index.nsf/0/e2ef65c93d5a9199802573aa0053e7fb/$FILE/GAEC%2014%202012%20v1.0.pdf "Download 'GAEC rules on protection of hedgerows and watercourses' (PDF, 1.08MB)"){:rel="external"}$D

Find more information on [hedgerow management and preservation](http://www.defra.gov.uk/food-farm/land-manage/landscape-features/hedgerows/ " hedgerow management and preservation"){:rel="external"} from the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra).

*[Defra]: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs
*[GAEC]: Good Agricultural and Environmental Condition

table.body:
The Forestry Commission has produced guidance on managing woodlands and minimising damage to them.
 
$D[Download 'Guide to the prevention of mammal damage' (PDF, 374KB)](http://adlib.everysite.co.uk/resources/000/111/058/fcPN3.pdf "Download 'Guide to prevention of mammal damage' (PDF, 374KB)"){:rel="external"}$D

$D[Download 'Guide on the prevention of rabbit damage' (PDF, 232KB)](http://adlib.everysite.co.uk/resources/000/111/027/fcpn2.pdf "Download 'Guide to prevention of rabbit damage' (PDF, 232KB)"){:rel="external"}$D

$D[Download 'Guide to the impact of deer on woodland biodiversity' (PDF, 127KB)](http://adlib.everysite.co.uk/resources/000/111/044/fcin36.pdf "Download 'Guide to the impact of deer on woodland' (PDF, 127KB)"){:rel="external"}$D

$D[Download 'Ancient woodland preservation guide' (PDF, 1.93MB)](http://adlib.everysite.co.uk/resources/000/123/933/fcpg014.pdf "Download 'Ancient woodland preservation guide' (PDF, 1.93MB)"){:rel="external"}$D 

 
##Tree felling and Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs)

You must get the written consent of your local planning authority before you damage or destroy, uproot, top or lop any trees that are protected by [TPOs.](http://www.communities.gov.uk/publications/planningandbuilding/tposguide "tree preservation order"){:rel="external"} 

You must also give 42 days written notice to your local planning authority if you wish to cut down any tree in a conservation area.

$D[Download 'GAEC 16 - Rules on felling of trees' (PDF, 676KB)](http://rpa.defra.gov.uk/rpa/index.nsf/15f3e119d8abcb5480256ef20049b53a/2f1ecc630b99df49802573870046fd7f/$FILE/GAEC%2016%202012%20v1.0.pdf "Download 'GAEC 16 - Rules on felling of trees' (PDF, 676KB)"){:rel="external"}$D
 
$D[Download 'GAEC 17 - Rules on Tree Preservation Orders' (PDF, 667KB)](http://rpa.defra.gov.uk/rpa/index.nsf/15f3e119d8abcb5480256ef20049b53a/c2a85013c58df6c48025738700527e56/$FILE/GAEC%2017%202012%20v1.0.pdf "Download 'GAEC 17 - Rules on Tree Preservation Orders' (PDF, 667KB)"){:rel="external"}$D



##Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) of forestry projects

You need an [EIA](http://www.communities.gov.uk/publications/planningandbuilding/environmentalimpactassessment "Environmental Impact Assessments"){:rel="external"} if you are:

* creating new woodland
* cutting down existing woodland
* doing forest road works
* doing forest-related quarrying 

You also need permission from the [Forestry Commission.](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/ "Forestry Commission"){:rel="external"} 


##Funding for woodlands

Payments for woodland are available under the [Single Payment Scheme and Farm Woodland Payments.](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/INFD-7S2FR5 "SPS and Farm Woodland Payments"){:rel="external"}

Funding is also available under [Environmental Stewardship.](http://www.defra.gov.uk/food-farm/land-manage/stewardship/ "Environmental Stewardship"){:rel="external"}  

###Woodland grants

$C
**English Woodland Grant Scheme hotline**  
01223 346 004
$C

The 7 woodland grants available under the Forestry Commission's [English Woodland Grant Scheme](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/ewgs "English Woodland Grant Scheme "){:rel="external"} are the:

* [Woodland Improvement Grant](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/infd-6dce98 "woodland improvement grant"){:rel="external"} - for the cost of ensuring better public benefits from existing woodlands 

* [Woodfuel Woodland Improvement Grant](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/infd-8nqegx "woodfuel woodland improvement grant"){:rel="external"} - for supporting sustainable production of woodfuel and other timber products

* [Woodland Creation Grant](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/infd-6dcegu "woodland creation grant"){:rel="external"} - to help establish new woodlands

* [Woodland Planning Grant](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/ewgs-wpg "woodland planning grant"){:rel="external"} - for the preparation of plans that help woodland management

* [Woodland Assessment Grant](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/INFD-6DCCYV "woodland assessment grant"){:rel="external"} - for the gathering of information to improve management decisions

* [Woodland Regeneration Grant](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/forestry/INFD-6DCD69 "woodland regeneration grant"){:rel="external"} - for improving woodland through natural regeneration and restocking after felling

* [Woodland Management Grant](http://www.forestry.gov.uk/ewgs-wmg "woodland management grant"){:rel="external"} - to support regular management of woodlands, such as pest control

Call the helpline if you require further information.

$C
**English Woodland Grant Scheme**  
01223 346 004
$C

*[EIA]: Environmental Impact Assessment
*[TPOs]: Tree Preservation Orders
*[GAEC]: Good Agricultural and Environmental Condition
table.title: Trees and woodland

table.body:
Stone walls of all types are important as landscape features and for stock management. Dry stone walls are walls made without the use of mortar or cement.

If you have dry stone walls on your land, you should:

* check their condition at least once a year
* remove any vegetation to help to ‘air’ the wall and prevent frost damage
* use local stone to make any repairs 
* prevent trees from growing alongside, as their roots can weaken wall foundations
 

%You must not remove a dry stone wall, or remove stone from it, except in special cases. %

[Read 'GAEC 13 - Rules on dry stone walls'](http://rpa.defra.gov.uk/rpa/index.nsf/vContentByTaxonomy/RPA%20Schemes**Single%20Payment%20Scheme**Cross%20Compliance**Farmer%20Guidance**Guide%20to%20Cross%20Compliance%20in%20England**GAECs**GAEC%2013**?OpenDocument "GAEC 13 rules on dry stone walls"){:rel="external"} or contact the Dry Stone Walling Association for more information.
  
$C
**Dry Stone Walling Association**  
01539 567963
$C

##Funding for dry stone walls

[Environmental Stewardship funding](http://www.defra.gov.uk/food-farm/land-manage/stewardship/ "Environmental Stewardship"){:rel="external"} is available to farmers and land managers for dry stone wall management.

Payments for dry stone walls are also available under the [Single Payment Scheme.](http://www.defra.gov.uk/food-farm/farm-manage/single-pay/ "Single Payment Scheme"){:rel="external"}

*[GAEC]: Good Agricultural and Environmental Condition
table.title: Dry stone walls

table.body:
A scheduled monument is a site which is legally protected because of its historical importance. 

Scheduled monuments might be:

* archaeological sites, such as ancient burial mounds
* 20th-century remains, such as from the coal industry or World War II

If you own or occupy a scheduled monument and want to carry out work on it, you'll need to get written permission from your [regional English Heritage office](http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/about/contact-us/offices/ "regional English Heritage offices"){:rel="external"}. You may also need to get planning permission from your council.

$D
[Download 'A Guide for Owners and Occupiers of Scheduled Monuments' (PDF, 61KB)](http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/publications/scheduled-monuments-guide-for-owners-and-occupiers/ " Download 'A Guide for Owners and Occupiers of Scheduled Monuments' (PDF, 61K)"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Grants for scheduled monuments

You may be able to get an [English Heritage grant](http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/professional/funding/grants/grants-available/ "scheduled monument grants"){:rel="external"} to help maintain or repair a scheduled monument.
